In a thrilling display of athleticism and determination, American triathlete Gwen Jorgensen secured her second consecutive world title with an impressive 15th victory in a row. Surging ahead on the run, she left her competitors, including the talented Stanford and Holland, trailing behind. The former world champion from Wales, Stanford, expressed the intense pressure of meeting the challenging criteria, emphasizing the sweat and effort poured into her performance. Meanwhile, Holland, grateful for her podium finish, reflected on the fierce competition during the run, knowing she had to keep pace to stay in contention. Jorgensen's remarkable finish time of one hour, 55 minutes, and 36 seconds solidified her dominance in the triathlon world, while Stanford's qualification for the Rio Olympics added to Wales' growing presence in the international sports arena.

GMB Scotland is currently facing a dire situation as the terms and conditions of its offshore industry members are being threatened. Seeking approval from the union's regional committee, officers are planning to conduct a ballot among members covered by the Offshore Contractors Agreement to gauge their willingness for potential strike action. This move mirrors a similar announcement made by Unite over the weekend, indicating the gravity of the situation. The North Sea has been witnessing a wave of job cuts and salary reductions by various oil and gas companies in response to the prolonged slump in oil prices. The breakdown in negotiations between the two unions and the Offshore Contractors Association (OCA) last Friday has only added fuel to the fire. The Offshore Contractors Agreement encompasses a wide range of workers in mechanical, electrical, construction, maintenance, design, project engineering, fabrication, and decommissioning sectors. Expressing his concerns, GMB Scotland regional officer John Kelly highlighted the "blatant opportunism" exhibited by certain oil companies and contractors in their concerted efforts to undermine the terms and conditions of their members.

The first half of the match between The Saddlers and Burton Albion was a tense affair, with both teams showing glimpses of potential to take the lead. The Albion goalkeeper, Jon McLaughlin, displayed his skill by keeping out attempts from Paul Downing and Romaine Sawyers, while Burton's Stuart Beavon came close with a tricky move that unfortunately ended in the side-netting. Despite the lack of goals, the match kept fans on the edge of their seats. Wigan's victory over Bury narrowed Albion's lead at the top of the table to just two points, with Walsall maintaining their position in fourth place. Nigel Clough, the manager of Burton Albion, emphasized the importance of the clean sheet and securing another point, highlighting the team's defensive strength. On the other hand, Walsall's head coach, Sean O'Driscoll, acknowledged the lack of open, free-flowing play but commended his team for their solid defensive performance, reflecting on their consistency in not giving anything away in previous seasons.

The prime minister's discussion of extradition rules with President Obama at the White House has sparked debate among critics who argue that the current regulations make it easier for UK nationals to be extradited to the US with minimal evidence required. Despite a senior judge's review in 2011 that deemed the extradition process fair to British citizens, concerns remain. During the two-hour meeting, Mr. Cameron expressed his reservations about the practical application of the rules, adding to the ongoing discussion surrounding the controversial 2003 US-UK extradition treaty. The prime minister's visit to the United States has shed light on cases like Christopher Tappin and Gary McKinnon, highlighting the need for a renegotiation of the treaty to address the imbalance in extradition procedures. As Parliament's Joint Committee on Human Rights joins the call for reform, the debate over extradition rules continues to evolve.

In Fiscal Kombat, players take on the role of Mr. Melenchon as they navigate the streets, engaging in battles against oligarchs and competing politicians. The primary objective is to acquire funds from the wealthy to finance Melenchon's proposed policies. Players must skillfully collect as much money as possible while evading attacks from the affluent individuals who are determined to thwart their efforts. The game features a variety of challenging "boss" encounters, including notable figures such as former president Nicolas Sarkozy, IMF chief Christine Lagarde, tax-evader Jerome Cahuzac, and L'Oreal heiress Liliane Bettencourt. Additionally, players must also face off against presidential contenders Emmanuel Macron and Francois Fillon. Originally conceived by Melenchon supporters who frequented the 18-25 chatroom on Jeuxvideo.com, a popular French gaming website, the game has garnered significant support from the candidate himself, further solidifying its place in the realm of political gaming.

The proposed merger between Bouygues Telecom and SFR, both major players in the French mobile phone industry, has sparked concerns about potential monopolistic practices. If the merger were to go through, it would significantly reduce competition in the market, leaving only three main mobile phone providers in France. This consolidation could lead to higher prices for consumers and a lack of choice in terms of service providers. Additionally, the bid by Altice, the owner of Numericable, to acquire SFR adds another layer of complexity to the situation. The competition regulators in both France and the European Union will need to carefully assess the potential impact of these mergers on the industry before granting approval. The trend of consolidation seen in the mobile phone industry is a cause for concern among industry analysts, as it could ultimately limit consumer options and lead to less competitive pricing.

Doreen Collyer, a former University of Chester lecturer, tragically lost her life while scuba diving in Perth after being attacked by a 16ft (5m) great white shark. Her husband, David Collyer, described her as a "beautiful person" and a "loving wife". The couple had relocated to Australia from Neston, Cheshire around five years ago. Mrs. Collyer held an advanced open water qualification and was an experienced diver. According to ABC, her diving partner was able to bring her to shore, but she sadly succumbed to her injuries at the scene. Prof Annette McIntosh-Scott, also from the University of Chester, paid tribute to Mrs. Collyer, highlighting her 15 years of dedicated service at the Faculty of Health and Social Care. She was known for her unwavering commitment to teaching and child healthcare, with her students always being the primary focus of her work. Mrs. Collyer's untimely passing has left a void in the hearts of those who knew and worked alongside her.

The sighting of a native American bird in England has sparked excitement among birdwatchers and experts alike. The appearance of the warbler, believed to have been blown across the Atlantic by Hurricane Gert while migrating to South America, has been described as "pretty amazing" by Martin Cade of Portland Bird Observatory. This marks the first time that this particular species has been observed in England, despite being common in the US where they migrate annually between North and South America. The unusual occurrence has been attributed to the bird possibly getting caught up in storms while crossing the Caribbean and being carried to Europe with strong winds. In addition to the sighting in England, another warbler has also been seen on Mizen Head in Ireland, further highlighting the extraordinary journey these birds have undertaken. Measuring about the size of a robin, the warbler has been observed feeding well and appearing active, leading experts to believe it may be stocking up on food before continuing its journey south to Spain and Africa. The rare sighting has attracted birdwatchers from various regions, reflecting the widespread interest and excitement generated by this unexpected visitor.

The 28-year-old Chile international, who recently scored the winning goal in Sunday's FA Cup semi-final match against Manchester City, still has a year remaining on his contract with Arsenal. Despite this, he has not yet agreed to a new deal. Manager Arsene Wenger emphasized that selling the player to another Premier League club is out of the question. Wenger expressed confidence that the player will stay and eventually sign a contract extension. Wenger himself has not confirmed his own future with the club, as his current contract expires at the end of the season. However, he is actively working on identifying transfer targets for the upcoming season, highlighting the importance of securing the club's future through strategic player acquisitions. Wenger remains focused on his responsibilities until the end of the current season, emphasizing the significance of planning for both the present and the future of the club.

Gene Palmer, the second prison worker implicated in the daring jail break, has joined Joyce Mitchell in facing charges related to the escape of Richard Matt and David Sweat from the Clinton Correctional Facility. The convicted killers utilized power tools to break free, sparking a massive manhunt that continues to this day. Palmer, accused of promoting prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence, and official misconduct, appeared before a judge and was granted bail. His attorney, Andrew Brockway, acknowledged that his client had unknowingly handed over hamburger meat to the inmates but claimed he had no knowledge of the tools hidden inside or the escape plan. Despite apologizing for his actions, Palmer plans to plead not guilty to the charges. Meanwhile, Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie revealed that Mitchell had played a key role in assisting the prisoners in their escape.

The H3 project, which was initiated in 2014, aims to streamline back office services for police, fire, and council authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, with the goal of saving up to £5m annually. However, the project has faced criticism from the Police Federation due to a series of errors, including payroll mistakes. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner has expressed confidence that the investment in the project will lead to improvements by May. A report to the Commissioner highlighted issues with recruitment, staff sickness management, and the burden of back office processes on police officers. In 2016, over 1,300 officers received incorrect pay, and allowances were wrongly calculated in March. Additionally, payment delays to Hampshire County Council's suppliers tripled under the new system. Hampshire Police Federation chairman John Apter has raised concerns about the impact of the system on operational effectiveness.

In a small town of Sleaford, a 22-year-old dreamer with a heart full of schemes, and a 25-year-old rebel from Bracknell, with fire in his eyes, found themselves in hot water on a Thursday night. Whispers in the shadows told tales of their daring escapades, trying to breach the fortress of Microsoft, from the frosty days of January to the blooming days of March. The law, with its unwavering gaze, caught wind of their misdeeds and charged them under the Computer Misuse Act, a stern reminder that the digital world is not a playground for the reckless. These two, mere pawns in a grand scheme, were part of a cunning group with eyes set on the treasure trove of customer data. In a swift move, the detectives of Serocu descended upon them, seizing their tools of mischief, leaving them to ponder the consequences of their digital dance with danger.

Jutanugarn's flawless performance in the third round of the tournament has put her in a prime position to potentially make history as the first Thai golfer to win a major tournament. With six birdies and no dropped shots, she is within reach of the tournament record-winning score of 19-under par. Mirim Lee of South Korea, who led in the first and second rounds, has slipped to second place after carding a 69. Catriona Matthew from Scotland will start the final round six shots behind in fourth place. Jutanugarn, who narrowly missed out on a major win earlier in the season, believes she has learned from that experience and is better equipped to handle the pressure. Her calm and consistent play in the third round reflects her confidence and determination to secure the victory on Sunday. As she approaches the final round, Jutanugarn remains focused on controlling what she can and staying composed under pressure.

At the prestigious IMF meeting in Washington, Christine Lagarde confidently asserted the success of the UK's economic strategies, emphasizing that the results were undeniable. In a poised manner, she downplayed any discrepancies between the IMF's deficit calculations and those of the Office for Budget Responsibility, attributing the variations to mere differences in methodology. Seated alongside George Osborne and Wolfgang Schaeuble, she articulated her belief that the figures, though calculated differently, ultimately pointed to the same conclusion. Lagarde astutely observed that in election years, forecasters tend to err on the side of caution, taking into account the uncertainties of political promises. With a subtle nod to the UK authorities, she praised their adept management of spending cuts and revenue generation, noting the positive impact on the country's growth rates compared to its European counterparts. Lagarde's words resonated with a sense of authority and insight, affirming her status as a formidable figure in the world of finance and economics.

Transport for London (TfL) has announced plans to conduct a consultation on proposed new regulations for private hire drivers, including the introduction of an English language test, a map-reading assessment, the requirement for a fixed landline, and the ability to book rides seven days in advance. Uber has expressed concerns that these regulations would fundamentally change their service and stated that it could potentially lead to the end of the Uber that customers have come to know and love. On the other hand, traditional black cab drivers have been advocating for stricter regulations to level the playing field. The pressure on city legislators has been mounting, with recent protests by cab drivers outside City Hall. Uber's app, which uses GPS technology to connect customers with nearby drivers and provide fare estimates, has disrupted the traditional taxi industry with its lower prices and cashless transactions. TfL has emphasized that the aim of the consultation is to improve industry standards in response to the rapid growth of the private hire sector and advancements in technology. Uber has criticized the proposals, claiming they are a direct attack on their business model and warning that they could lead to increased prices and worsened congestion on city streets.

The world of music festivals is a vibrant and diverse one, with attendees ranging from casual fans to dedicated "superfans" who spare no expense in pursuit of their passion. According to a recent survey of 504 UK residents who had attended at least one festival in the last year, these "superfans" are predominantly male and are willing to shell out an average of £581 annually on festival experiences. They often opt for VIP passes or upgraded camping options, and are more likely than most consumers to purchase music in physical formats such as CDs or digital downloads. Eventbrite, the ticketing website that commissioned the survey, notes that these dedicated fans play a crucial role in driving the music festivals market, frequently recommending music and events to their friends. Despite only accounting for 28% of the festival-going audience, these "superfans" are willing to attend events alone and spend an average of £45 more per event than casual fans. However, their loyalty is not guaranteed, with 46% expressing concerns that festivals are becoming "too corporate". With over 100 music festivals held in the UK each year, from iconic events like Glastonbury to smaller, niche gatherings, there is no shortage of options for music lovers to choose from.

In the bustling world of the markets, the sterling soared against the dollar, reaching new heights at $1.32.40, a rise of 1.86%, while also making gains against the euro, standing strong at â‚¬1.19.57, a 1.73% increase. The FTSE 100 share index danced with the stars, hitting an impressive 11-month peak before gracefully descending back to earth and settling at 6,680.69, a mere slip of 2.17 points or 0.03%. Meanwhile, the FTSE 250 index, with its focus on the UK, seemed to have found its rhythm, climbing 68.75 points, a 0.4% increase, to land at 16,775.14. The property sector, once shaken by the Brexit storm, found solace in Galliford Try, who announced promising full-year profit expectations, causing their shares to soar by 8.5%. Financial stocks, scarred by the aftermath of the referendum, also found their footing. Aviva's shares rose by an impressive 4.26%, while Lloyds Banking Group seemed to be on the road to recovery.

The incident involving the MV Karen and the British submarine highlights a concerning lack of communication and awareness on the part of the military. The fact that the submarine failed to correctly identify the fishing vessel and its nets in the water raises questions about the level of training and technology in place to ensure such accidents do not occur. The delay in acknowledging the submarine's involvement and the subsequent cost of £10,000 to repair the damage further adds to the frustration and inconvenience faced by the crew of the MV Karen. The Ministry of Defence's initial refusal to comment on submarine activity only added to the confusion and lack of transparency surrounding the incident. The statement from Minister for the Armed Forces Penny Mordaunt expressing regret over the incident and its consequences is a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done to prevent similar incidents in the future. Overall, this incident serves as a reminder of the potential dangers and consequences of military activities in civilian waters.

The tragic death of Kian Delos Santos at the hands of the police has sparked outrage and grief across the Philippines. The circumstances surrounding his death, with evidence suggesting he was killed while kneeling and facing down, have raised serious questions about police brutality and the ongoing violent campaign against drugs led by President Duterte. The funeral procession for Kian was a poignant moment, with hundreds of mourners demanding justice and an end to the extrajudicial killings that have become all too common in the country. The presence of nuns, priests, and children chanting for justice added a solemn and powerful tone to the proceedings. Kian's father's impassioned plea for accountability from the police resonated with many, highlighting the deep sense of loss and frustration felt by his family and the community at large. The call for compassion and justice in the face of such tragedy is a reminder of the need for a more humane and just approach to tackling the issue of drug-related crime in the Philippines.

Construction on the new lane, which runs alongside part of the existing canal, began less than a year ago. The 72km (44 mile) route allows for two-way traffic and can accommodate larger vessels, making it a significant upgrade to the original Suez Canal. During a recent trial run, several container ships from various countries successfully navigated the new lane, under the watchful eye of helicopters and naval vessels providing security. The Sinai Peninsula, which borders the canal, has been a hotspot for Islamic militants, posing a threat to the security of the region. Since the overthrow of President Mohammed Morsi in 2013, these militants have carried out numerous attacks, resulting in the loss of hundreds of lives. The original Suez Canal, which opened nearly 150 years ago, serves as a crucial link between the Mediterranean and the Red Sea. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi believes that the expansion of this vital shipping route will not only boost trade but also create job opportunities across the country. Currently handling 7% of global sea-borne trade, the Suez Canal plays a significant role in the global economy.

Leeds Crown Court was told about the disturbing history of James Carragher, who had previously been sentenced to seven years in 1993 and 14 years in 2004 for sexual offenses. He now faces 50 counts of indecent assault allegations from the 1970s to the 1990s at St William's in Market Weighton, East Riding of Yorkshire. This home for troubled boys was under the management of the Catholic De La Salle order but has since been shut down. Mr. Carragher, who served as the head of St William's from 1976 to 1990, along with two other individuals, is accused of abusing 19 former students. The prosecution, led by Richard Wright QC, described Mr. Carragher as someone with a disturbing and persistent interest in young boys. He operated behind a facade of respectability, making it difficult for anyone to believe the allegations against him.

The 23-year-old defender completed his move to Rangers on a three-year contract, with the transfer fee remaining undisclosed. Speaking to Rangers TV, he expressed his determination to succeed in his new environment, acknowledging the need to adapt to a different country and lifestyle. Cardoso emphasized his commitment to giving his all on the pitch to help his team secure victories, highlighting the importance of winning for a club of Rangers' stature. Having represented Portugal at the Under-21 level, he featured in 23 matches for Vitoria Setubal in the previous season before making the switch from Benfica. Cardoso is the second Portuguese centre-back to arrive at Rangers this summer, following the arrival of experienced international Bruno Alves from Cagliari. The squad at Ibrox has also welcomed midfielder Dalcio, who has joined on loan from Benfica.

Long-time Mugabe critic Morgan Tsvangirai and former Vice-President Joice Mujuru have announced their decision to collaborate in the upcoming election, though the specifics regarding their presidential candidate remain uncertain. President Mugabe, who has held power for over three decades, has expressed his intention to run for re-election at the age of 93. Mr. Tsvangirai emphasized the importance of this alliance as a foundational step towards a broader coalition to challenge the ruling Zanu-PF party in the lead-up to the election. This collaboration marks a significant milestone in uniting a fractured opposition, and if successful, it would present President Mugabe with a unified opposition front for the first time since he assumed office in 1980. This development signals a potentially transformative shift in Zimbabwean politics, with the hopes of fostering a more competitive electoral landscape in the upcoming election.

During a meeting with a group of MEPs on Wednesday, Jean-Claude Juncker discussed his support for democratic processes and his respect for Scotland's upcoming referendum. He emphasized that he would await the outcome of the vote before making any statements. When questioned about the potential EU membership of Catalonia and Scotland, Mr Juncker highlighted that simply writing a letter is not sufficient for EU membership. Catalan MEP Josep Maria Terricabras raised concerns about Mr Juncker's stance on the Scottish independence referendum, prompting the official to reiterate his commitment to respecting the democratic decision of the Scottish people. In a separate exchange with Scottish UKIP MEP David Coburn, Mr Juncker acknowledged that the issue of Scotland's EU membership would ultimately be determined by the UK.

The students' posts on the Facebook chat forum were highly disturbing and offensive, touching on incredibly sensitive topics such as child abuse, sexual assault, paedophilia, and the Holocaust. In addition, racial slurs were directed at minorities, further adding to the hateful content of the messages. Harvard University's response to the situation was met with criticism from free speech advocates, who deemed the punishment meted out to the students as overly severe. The actions taken by the university were reported by the Crimson, the prestigious college's main student newspaper. The chat forum in question was originally formed as a side group for incoming Harvard students interested in sharing memes and other "adult" content. Prospective members were required to submit a "provocative" meme in order to gain entry. However, the group's existence was short-lived as Harvard administrators swiftly caught wind of its content and launched an investigation into the matter.

Community leaders from Santa Clara County took a stand on Monday by filing a notice of intention to collect signatures for the recall of Judge Aaron Persky in the upcoming year. This action was sparked by the controversy surrounding Persky's lenient sentencing of Stanford University swimmer Brock Turner in June 2016. Despite facing a possible 14-year sentence, Turner was only given six months, of which he served just three, for the sexual assault of an unconscious woman. The decision left many outraged, with the notice to circulate a recall petition stating that Judge Persky's ruling had shocked the global community. Leading the charge is Stanford law professor Michele Dauber, who, along with a coalition of 50 community leaders, emphasized the importance of having a judge who prioritizes the protection of victims over the protection of perpetrators. Dauber stressed the urgency of addressing the prevalent issue of rape culture and expressed determination to bring about change through this recall effort.

Entrants to the annual event have the opportunity to showcase their storytelling skills by presenting the most elaborate and convincing lie they can come up with in just five minutes. This year, the title of the best liar went to George Kemp, a resident of Maryport, Cumbria, who was surprised by his victory due to battling a chest infection at the time. Kemp's winning tale involved an unlikely encounter with Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel, which he claimed was the result of building a makeshift submarine using his father's old bubble car. According to Kemp, this submarine journey took him to the Isle of Man where he crossed paths with various celebrities inside a Scottish submarine crafted from shortbread tins. In his fabricated narrative, political figures Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond were even depicted as entrepreneurs selling these unique shortbread tin submarines to the United States of America. Despite his valiant effort, last year's champion Mike Naylor, also known as Monkey Liar, had to settle for second place, while Helen Jordan secured the third spot. It is worth noting that illustrious personalities like comedian and television host Sue Perkins have also claimed victory in this whimsical competition in the past.

During the investigation, it was revealed that a mere 28% of Welsh speakers had utilized the language when interacting with their healthcare professionals such as GPs, dentists, and opticians. This concerning statistic prompted Ms. Huws to express her hope that the report would mark a turning point in ensuring that patients can receive healthcare that caters to their linguistic needs. Government ministers, in response to the report, committed to providing a formal response within six months. The inquiry, which gathered insights from over a thousand Welsh speakers, highlighted that 90% of them believed they should have the right to use Welsh when engaging with the NHS, regardless of their location in Wales. Furthermore, the findings revealed that Welsh speakers often felt uncomfortable and faced challenges in articulating their concerns to English-speaking healthcare providers. The report put forth a total of 33 recommendations to the Welsh government, urging them to take decisive action by offering a clear policy framework to primary care providers, along with an actionable plan and timeline for implementing necessary changes.

The bill at hand seeks to amend certain provisions of the 2016 Trade Union Act passed by the UK government. If approved, it would result in changes to the current limitations on industrial action within key sectors such as the NHS, fire service, schools, and other devolved services in Wales. The UK government asserts that matters concerning industrial relations fall under the jurisdiction of Westminster. A central tenet of the existing law is the requirement for a strike to be endorsed by at least 40% of a union's members in a ballot. However, members of the Welsh Assembly's Equality, Local Government and Communities Committee have reached a consensus on the necessity of this new legislation to uphold Wales' tradition of fostering social partnership. Welsh Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford strongly criticized any attempts by London ministers to impede the progress of the Welsh Trade Union Bill, labeling it as a potential "democratic outrage." The Welsh Labour Government contends that restrictions on union activities in devolved services, like the NHS and schools, should not be dictated by UK ministers. The committee's report did encounter opposition from Conservative AM Janet Finch-Saunders, who disagreed with the proposed changes.

Evha Jannath, an 11-year-old student, tragically fell from a circular boat on the Splash Canyon ride at Drayton Manor while on a school trip. Following this incident, other amusement parks such as Alton Towers and Legoland Windsor have made the decision to temporarily close similar water-based white knuckle rides. Drayton Manor has announced that it will remain closed on Friday in order to conduct thorough health and safety investigations. In response to the tragedy, Merlin Entertainments, the company that operates Legoland and Alton Towers, has taken precautionary measures by closing similar rides at their parks. They have stated that these rides are expected to reopen on Friday after necessary safety checks have been completed. However, some amusement parks like Lightwater Valley in North Yorkshire and West Midland Safari Park have chosen not to close their rides in light of the incident at Drayton Manor.

The Championship winners, Rangers, secured a commanding victory with an early own goal from Ally Gilchrist and a powerful strike from James Tavernier. Andy Halliday added to the tally with a penalty, and Kenny Miller sealed the win by tapping in a goal. This triumph marked Rangers' fourth attempt at the trophy, finally coming out victorious. Looking ahead, their next challenge awaits in the form of Celtic in the Scottish Cup semi-final. It has been a long journey for Rangers in the Challenge Cup, as they have faced setbacks against Queen of the South, Raith Rovers, and Alloa Athletic in previous years. Despite the struggles, they have now emerged as champions and are set to face the Premiership leaders at Hampden Park. The national stadium will have a new pitch installed, a much-needed upgrade from the subpar surface that Rangers and League One Peterhead had to contend with. The current pitch, laid just five weeks ago at a hefty cost, failed to meet expectations and will be replaced before the upcoming match. The underdog part-timers of Peterhead put up a valiant effort, despite being 22-1 outsiders in the competition.

The decision by members of the Royal College of Midwives (RCM) to engage in a four-hour work stoppage marks a significant moment in the history of the institution, which has stood for 134 years. The overwhelming majority vote of 9-1 in favor of strike action demonstrates the deep-seated concerns and frustrations among midwives regarding their pay and working conditions. In response, the Department of Health expressed disappointment at the decision but assured the public that measures would be taken to ensure the safety of mothers and babies during the strike. Despite the tensions, the Department emphasized its willingness to engage in dialogue and find a resolution to the dispute. The RCM, on the other hand, is actively seeking urgent discussions with the health minister to address the issue at hand. Bredagh Hughes, RCM NI director, clarified that the midwives' demands for a 1% pay increase align with those granted to their counterparts in other parts of the UK. She emphasized that the dispute is not aimed at putting women at risk but rather at addressing systemic issues within the healthcare system. With full emergency cover in place, the midwives on strike are prepared to uphold their commitment to providing quality care while advocating for fair treatment from their employers and the Department of Health.

The recent fraudulent attack on Tesco Bank, initially believed to have impacted 20,000 current account customers, has been revealed to have affected fewer than half of that figure. Fortunately, the bank assured that personal data remained secure, with no compromise during the breach. All affected accounts have since been reimbursed, bringing some relief to those affected by the incident. The bank described the attack as "systematic and sophisticated," a concerning revelation that highlights the increasing threat of cybercrime in today's digital age. Chief executive Benny Higgins expressed his gratitude for the patience of customers as the bank worked diligently to resolve the issue. He reassured customers that online debit transactions have been reinstated, allowing normal account activity to resume. Despite the inconvenience caused, Higgins extended a sincere apology to all affected customers, acknowledging the distress and uncertainty they may have experienced during this challenging time. While the bank has identified the nature of the attack, questions remain about the perpetrators behind this calculated breach of security.

Construction workers across the UK are required to possess a CSCS card in order to demonstrate their skills and knowledge of health and safety protocols. However, a recent joint investigation by BBC London and Newsnight uncovered a troubling trend of organized cheating within the industry. Carl Rhymer, representing the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB), revealed that as many as 6,000 card-holders would need to retake their exams due to fraudulent practices. The CSCS card, considered the flagship certification scheme for builders in the UK, is mandatory for employees of nine major construction companies, as well as for projects like Crossrail and Heathrow. The investigation revealed that several test centers were offering guaranteed passes in exchange for money, allowing individuals with limited English proficiency to obtain qualifications and gain access to hazardous construction sites. One such center, Wep HSE in Ealing, was exposed for unethical practices after its director, Garet Estensen, was caught reading exam answers from a large screen and instructing candidates to follow along for the correct responses. When confronted with the evidence, Mr. Estensen chose not to comment. Two other test centers, including Future Training 4, were also implicated in the investigation for similar dishonest practices.

The hackers behind the cyber attack on the city's transport network have demanded a ransom of 100 Bitcoin, equivalent to approximately $70,000. To prevent further damage, all ticketing machines on the network were promptly shut down by staff. Screens at various stations displayed a message from the hackers, stating that all data had been encrypted and providing an email address for victims to contact in order to obtain the decryption key. The email address provided belonged to Yandex, a Russian internet company offering various online services. Despite the disruption caused by the attack, the trains themselves were not affected, and city officials assured the public that there was no impact on transit services, safety systems, or customer information. An investigation into the incident was underway, with the Municipal Transportation Agency, responsible for managing trains, trams, and buses in the city, working to identify the perpetrators and ensure the security of the network. Additional details were not disclosed at that time as the investigation was ongoing.

The British pair, consisting of Sir Bradley Wiggins and Mark Cavendish, faced a tough defeat in the final race, the madison, at the hands of Moreno de Pauw and Kenny de Ketele of Belgium. Despite the loss, Wiggins, at 36 years old, had originally planned to retire after the Six Day event in Ghent in November. However, during a post-race interview, he playfully mentioned the possibility of a change of heart, jokingly stating, "Money talks." His love for racing was evident as he reflected on the exhilarating week of competition, leaving the door open for a potential return to the sport. The Lee Valley velodrome, where the event took place, held a special significance for Wiggins, as it was the same venue that hosted the London 2012 track events. The velodrome was also built on the site of the Eastway facility where Wiggins honed his skills as a young cyclist. With five Olympic gold medals to his name, Wiggins expressed gratitude for the memories created at the velodrome and hinted at the possibility of returning in a different capacity next year, perhaps as a spectator in the stands. The event, which kicked off last Tuesday, showcased the dynamic duo of Wiggins and Cavendish as they competed against top-tier cyclists in a thrilling display of skill and sportsmanship.

The Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) report provided a detailed analysis of the tragic crash involving pilot Andy Hill and the Hawker Hunter plane on 22 August. The report highlighted that cockpit footage showed the plane responding to the pilot's control inputs, raising questions about the sequence of events leading up to the crash. In a shocking revelation, it was disclosed that Mr Hill was thrown clear of the aircraft during the later part of the crash, leaving investigators uncertain about whether he initiated his ejection. The report further detailed that the Hawker Hunter's canopy was released upon impact, leading to the release of fuel and fuel vapour which ignited, causing the jet to split into four parts. Mr Hill and his seat were both thrown clear of the cockpit, prompting the investigation to determine if the pilot attempted to initiate ejection or if the canopy and seat were liberated due to impact damage. This troubling information from the AAIB report raises concerns about the safety protocols and mechanisms in place during such high-risk aviation situations.

The World Half Marathon Championship will bring together around 200 of the world's top athletes along with up to 25,000 amateur runners on Saturday, 26 March. The race will cover a distance of 13.1 miles, starting outside Cardiff Castle and finishing on King Edward VII Avenue in the city centre. Dave Bedford, ex-10,000m world record holder, praised the course, describing it as flat and showcasing the best of Cardiff, from its historic sites to its modern attractions. The route will take participants past iconic landmarks such as the Millennium Stadium, Cardiff City Stadium, Penarth Marina, the Cardiff Bay Barrage, the Wales Millennium Centre, and Roath Park Lake before concluding with a grandstand finish in the heart of the capital. This marks the first time the World Half Marathon Championship will be held in Wales, building on Cardiff's reputation as a premier racing destination since hosting an annual half marathon since 2003. The event is expected to further elevate the city's standing in the racing world, especially with the recent success of double Olympic gold medalist Mo Farah in long-distance events.

The establishment of the Local Nature Reserve from Bo'ness Harbour to the former Kinneil colliery signifies a significant step towards the preservation and enhancement of wildlife and plant species in the Falkirk Council area. This initiative, the second of its kind in the region, represents a pivotal moment in the transformation of a site with a long history of heavy industrial use. Following the closure of its central colliery in 1983, the area has undergone a transition from a hub of industrial activity to a sanctuary for biodiversity. Notably, the designation of the mudflats and "island" off the foreshore as a Special Protection Area underscores the ecological significance of this landscape. The decision to bestow reserve status on the Kinneil foreshore is expected to attract much-needed funding for conservation efforts and further promote the area's environmental importance. Councillor Adrian Mahoney, convener of leisure, tourism, and community, expressed his enthusiasm for this milestone, emphasizing the historical and ecological value of the Kinneil site in the wake of the closure of Kinneil Colliery, the area's last remaining pit, three decades ago.

Spencer Flower, a Conservative councillor from Verwood, Dorset, faced legal repercussions in 2013 due to his involvement with a social housing company. Despite claiming that his ties to the firm were irrelevant to the housing debate in east Dorset, Flower was found guilty of illegally voting on a plan that could have benefitted the company. The district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court determined that Flower had violated laws outlined in the Localism Act 2011. As a result, Flower received a six-month conditional discharge and was ordered to pay £930 in costs. While he was allowed to continue serving in public office, Flower refrained from commenting on his political future following the court's decision. Despite expressing surprise and disappointment at the outcome, Flower acknowledged the court's ruling and stressed that there was no personal gain or intent involved in his actions.

The late singer Cilla Black, who passed away in 2015, achieved commercial success in the music industry with her UK top 10 hit "It's for You" in 1964. This song, written by the iconic duo of Paul McCartney and John Lennon, became a significant milestone in Black's career. Interestingly, McCartney had recorded his own version of the song earlier that year and personally delivered it to Black while she was performing at the prestigious London Palladium. However, this recording was thought to have been lost or destroyed until Black's nephew stumbled upon it. Subsequently, the rare disc was put up for auction at the Beatles Memorabilia Auction held at Unity Theatre in Liverpool, where it fetched an impressive sum of £18,000. With the addition of commission fees, the final amount paid by the anonymous buyer totaled £21,060. Simon White, an expert in Beatles memorabilia, expressed his belief in the significance and value of this unique piece of music history.

Mr. Clarke's frustration with the excessive options and lengthy recorded information on call centre menus led him to embark on a project aimed at addressing this issue. He found that some automated menus had as many as 80 options, resulting in lengthy wait times for callers trying to reach the desired service. For instance, contacting an adviser at HM Revenue and Customs only required pressing four buttons, but navigating through each menu level could take up to six minutes, according to Mr. Clarke. In response to these concerns, HMRC stated that they were actively working on improving their interactive voice responses and preparing to implement new speech recognition technology. This technology will allow the system to respond to callers' spoken requests instead of requiring them to select options by pressing buttons on their phones. HMRC plans to roll out these improvements later this year, in line with their commitment to enhancing the efficiency and user experience of their call centre services.

Envoy Sigrid Kaag stood before the press, her expression grave and determined, as she addressed the world on the latest developments in Syria. The country had failed to meet the Sunday deadline for the removal of its chemical weapons, a crucial step in the process of their destruction by 30 June. The Russian-US agreement to eliminate Syria's arsenal had been forged in the wake of a devastating sarin rocket attack that claimed the lives of hundreds of innocent civilians near Damascus. The multinational effort to rid Syria of its chemical weapons was being closely monitored by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). Despite the looming deadline, Damascus had previously pledged to have its entire stockpile removed by 27 April, a promise that had yet to be fulfilled. With the bulk of the chemical weapons material already removed but not yet destroyed, the pressure was on to ensure that the remaining stockpile was swiftly and safely disposed of. Ms. Kaag emphasized the urgency of the situation, stressing the importance of completing the mission before the 30 June deadline.
